revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Achyranthes aspera |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 204. 1753 |year=1753 |other_info_on_pub=name conserved }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Centrostachys aspera |authority=(Linnaeus) Standley |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Amaranthaceae;Achyranthes;Achyranthes aspera |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Amaranthaceae]]
genus[[Achyranthes]]
species[[Achyranthes aspera]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 435 |treatment_page=page 436 }}Plants perennial or annual. Stems 0.4–2 m, pilose or puberulent. Leaf blades elliptic, ovate, or broadly ovate to orbiculate, obovate-orbiculate, or broadly rhombate, 1–20 × 2–6 cm, adpressed-pubescent abaxially and adaxially. Inflorescences to 30 cm; bracts membranous; bracteoles long-aristate, spinose; wings attached at sides and base. Flowers: tepals 4 or 5, length 3–7 mm; pseudostaminodes with margins fimbriate at apex, often with dorsal scale. Utricles ± cylindric, 2–4 mm, apex truncate or depressed.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;La.;Md.;S.C.;Tex.;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America;Eurasia;Africa. |discussion=

Varieties 6 (2 in the flora).

Achyranthes aspera is a variable, pantropical species divided into six varieties (C. C. Townsend 1974), two of which occur in the flora. The variety with a long perianth and acuminate leaves has long been called var. aspera; the variety with a short perianth and blunt leaves, var. indica. However, A. Cavaco (1962) showed that the type of var. indica must be the type of the species A. aspera, thus var. indica is a homotypic synonym of var. aspera. Townsend made the combination A. aspera var. pubescens for plants previously called var. aspera.

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaf blades elliptic, ovate, or broadly ovate, apex acuminate; tepals 6-7 mm |[[Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens|Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaf blades orbiculate, obovate-orbiculate, or broadly rhombate, apex rounded, apiculate; tepals 3-4 mm |[[Achyranthes aspera var. aspera|Achyranthes aspera var. aspera]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Achyranthes aspera |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Centrostachys aspera |basionyms= |family=Amaranthaceae |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;La.;Md.;S.C.;Tex.;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America;Eurasia;Africa. |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1753 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_854.xml |genus=Achyranthes |species=Achyranthes aspera }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Achyranthes]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Achyranthes aspera var. aspera |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Achyranthes aspera var. indica |authority= |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Achyranthes indica |authority=(Linnaeus) Standley |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Centrostachys indica |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Amaranthaceae;Achyranthes;Achyranthes aspera;Achyranthes aspera var. aspera |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Amaranthaceae]]
genus[[Achyranthes]]
species[[Achyranthes aspera]]
variety[[Achyranthes aspera var. aspera]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 436 }}Leaf blades orbiculate, obovate-orbiculate, or broadly rhombate, 1–4(–6) × 1–4(–6) cm, base rounded or tapering, apex rounded, apiculate. Tepals 3–4 mm. Utricles 2–2.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Dry, sandy waste places, near woolen mills |elevation=0-100 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;La.;S.C.;Asia. |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Achyranthes aspera var. aspera |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Achyranthes aspera var. indica;Achyranthes indica;Centrostachys indica |basionyms= |family=Amaranthaceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Dry, sandy waste places, near woolen mills |elevation=0-100 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;La.;S.C.;Asia. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Introduced;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_855.xml |genus=Achyranthes |species=Achyranthes aspera |variety=Achyranthes aspera var. aspera }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Achyranthes aspera]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens |accepted_authority=(Moquin-Tandon) C. C. Townsend |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Kew Bull. |place=29: 473. 1974 |year=1974 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Achyranthes fruticosa var. pubescens |authority=Moquin-Tandon |rank=variety |publication_title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |publication_place=13(2): 314. 1849 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Amaranthaceae;Achyranthes;Achyranthes aspera;Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Amaranthaceae]]
genus[[Achyranthes]]
species[[Achyranthes aspera]]
variety[[Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 437 |treatment_page=page 436 }}Leaf blades elliptic, ovate, or broadly ovate, 4–20 × 2–5 cm, base rounded or narrowed, apex acuminate. Tepals 6–7 mm. Utricles 3–4 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Waste places, chrome ore piles, hammocks |elevation=0-10 m |distribution=Fla.;Md.;Tex.;West Indies. |discussion=

Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens may be native in southern Florida; it is introduced in Maryland.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens |authority=(Moquin-Tandon) C. C. Townsend |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Achyranthes fruticosa var. pubescens |family=Amaranthaceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Waste places, chrome ore piles, hammocks |elevation=0-10 m |distribution=Fla.;Md.;Tex.;West Indies. |reference=None |publication title=Kew Bull. |publication year=1974 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_856.xml |genus=Achyranthes |species=Achyranthes aspera |variety=Achyranthes aspera var. pubescens }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Achyranthes aspera]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Achyranthes japonica |accepted_authority=(Miquel) Nakai |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bot. Mag. (Tokyo) |place=34: 39. 1920 |year=1920 }} |common_names=Japanese chaff-flower |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Achyranthes bidentata var. japonica |authority=Miquel |rank=variety |publication_title=Ann. Mus. Bot. Lugduno-Batavi |publication_place=2: 132. 1865 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Amaranthaceae;Achyranthes;Achyranthes japonica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Amaranthaceae]]
genus[[Achyranthes]]
species[[Achyranthes japonica]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 435 |treatment_page=page 437 }}Plants perennial. Stems 0.75–1.5 m, glabrous or slightly pubescent. Leaf blades ovate-elliptic, 2.5–13.5 × 0.2–6.8 cm, base tapering, apex acute to acuminate, pubescent on veins abaxially, short-pubescent adaxially, varying to glabrous or glabrescent. Inflorescences 2–4 cm in flower, elongating to 21 cm in fruit; bracteoles spinose; basal wings attached at base and sometimes slightly on sides. Flowers: tepals 5, 4–5 mm; pseudostaminodes with margins entire, denticulate, or slightly 2-lobed at apex. Utricles elliptic, 2.5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Wooded riverbanks |elevation=100-200 m |distribution=Ky.;Ohio;W.Va.;Asia. |introduced=true |discussion=

The plants of Achyranthes japonica in our area evidently belong to var. hachijoensis Honda, which has glabrous or glabrescent leaves.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=medley1985a |text=Medley, M. E., H. Bryan, J. MacGregor, and J. W. Thieret. 1985. Achyranthes japonica (Miq.) Nakai (Amaranthaceae) in Kentucky and West Virginia: New to North America. Sida 11: 92–95. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Achyranthes japonica |authority=(Miquel) Nakai |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Achyranthes bidentata var. japonica |family=Amaranthaceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Wooded riverbanks |elevation=100-200 m |distribution=Ky.;Ohio;W.Va.;Asia. |introduced=true |reference=medley1985a |publication title=Bot. Mag. (Tokyo) |publication year=1920 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_857.xml |genus=Achyranthes |species=Achyranthes japonica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Achyranthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Achyronychia |accepted_authority=Torrey & A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=7: 330. 1868 |year=1868 }} |common_names=Onyx flower;frost-mat |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae;Achyronychia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae]]
genus[[Achyronychia]]
|etymology=Greek achuron, chaff, and onyx, onychos, nail or fingernail, alluding to the chaffy sepals |volume=Volume 5 |mention_page=page 5, 29, 47 |treatment_page=page 46 }}Herbs, annual. Taproots slender. Stems prostrate to ascending, branched, terete to angular, base glabrous. Leaves opposite, connate or connected by thickened ridge or transverse wing from which stipules arise, sessile; stipules 2 per node, white, ovate to spatulate, margins fringed to ciliate, apex ± entire; blade obscurely 1-veined, spatulate, somewhat succulent, apex rounded. Inflorescences axillary cymes proliferating throughout length of stem; bracts paired, resembling stipules, smaller. Flowers sessile; hypanthium cylindric to urceolate, abruptly expanded proximally and distally in fruit; sepals 5, distinct, green, broadly ovate to orbiculate or reniform, 1.2–1.5 mm, herbaceous, margins white, scarious, apex broadly rounded, not hooded, not awned; nectaries at filament bases subtended adaxially by flaps of tissue; stamens 1–4; filaments distinct to base; staminodes 14–19, arising from hypanthium rim, filiform; styles 2, connate in proximal 1/2, filiform, 0.2–0.4 mm, glabrous proximally; stigmas 2, linear along adaxial surface of styles, obscurely papillate (50×). Modified utricles obconic, opening by 8 or 10, not spreading, toothlike valves. Seeds tan with red spot near one end, ovoid, slightly laterally compressed, smooth, marginal wing absent, appendage absent; embryo peripheral, straight to slightly curved.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=sw United States;Mexico. |discussion=

Species 1.

Based on characters of the seeds and flowers, Achyronychia is closely related to and possibly congeneric with Scopulophila.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Achyronychia |author=Ronald L. Hartman |authority=Torrey & A. Gray |rank=genus |parent rank=subfamily |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |illustrator=Yevonn Wilson-Ramsey |illustration copyright=Flora of North America Association |distribution=sw United States;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication year=1868 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_92.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae |genus=Achyronychia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Achyronychia cooperi |accepted_authority=Torrey & A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=7: 331. 1868 |year=1868 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Caryophyllaceae;Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae;Achyronychia;Achyronychia cooperi |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Caryophyllaceae]]
subfamily[[Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae]]
genus[[Achyronychia]]
species[[Achyronychia cooperi]]
|volume=Volume 5 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 47 }}Stems 3–17 cm, mostly glabrous. Leaves pairs unequal; stipules 0.1–0.4 mm; blade 3–20 mm. Inflorescences 20–60+-flowered. Flowers: perianth 2.5–3 mm; hypanthium green, becoming brown and hard, 10-ribbed distally; sepals erect to spreading, concave, central portion green, fleshy, white, scarious portion forming an ovate to orbiculate apex, 1–1.3+ mm wide, becoming deciduous with age; staminodes ca. 0.5 mm. Seeds 0.9–1.1 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring. |habitat=Dry, sandy areas, sand dunes, desert washes |elevation=50-700 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Achyronychia cooperi |authority=Torrey & A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Caryophyllaceae |phenology=Flowering spring. |habitat=Dry, sandy areas, sand dunes, desert washes |elevation=50-700 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication year=1868 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V5/V5_93.xml |subfamily=Caryophyllaceae subfam. Paronychioideae |genus=Achyronychia |species=Achyronychia cooperi }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Achyronychia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |place=2, 15: 259. 1853 |year=1853 }} |common_names=Trumpets |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ammocodon |authority=Standley |rank=genus }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Selinocarpus |authority=A. Gray |rank=genus }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
|etymology=Greek a, without, cleis, thing that closes, and anthos, flower; alluding to lack of involucre |volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 14, 16, 17 |treatment_page=page 33 }}Plants perennial, finely pubescent, from stout taproots. Stems prostrate to erect, often clambering through other vegetation, slender to ± stout, herbaceous or woody, unarmed, without glutinous bands on internodes. Leaves sessile to petiolate, subequal to greatly unequal in each pair, ± thick and succulent, base asymmetric or ± symmetric. Inflorescences terminal or axillary, solitary flowers or few-flowered cymes and nearly sessile, or short pedicellate in 3–25-flowered umbellate clusters in axils or forks of branches; bracts persistent, not accrescent, 1–3 beneath each flower, distinct, narrowly lanceolate, small or minute, herbaceous. Flowers bisexual, chasmogamous and/or cleistogamous; cleistogamous perianth narrow domelike tube atop basal portion; chasmogamous perianth radially symmetric, short to elongate funnelform, constricted beyond ovary, abruptly expanded to 5-lobed limb; stamens 2(–3) or 5–6 (2–5 in cleistogamous flowers), exserted; styles exserted beyond anthers; stigmas peltate. Fruits oblong or narrowly ellipsoid, coriaceous, smooth, glabrous or minutely puberulent; ribs 5, rounded, often with large, dark, sticky gland near apex, or wings 3–5, coriaceous, hyaline, often between ribs or wings a rib or low sharp ridge.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=sw United States;n Mexico;ne Africa. |discussion=

Species 17 (12 in the flora).

R. A. Levin (2000) showed that Selinocarpus is paraphyletic and embedded within Acleisanthes. All species are pubescent on young stems and leaves. Older leaves may be glabrate or glabrous.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=fowler1977a |text=Fowler, B. A. and B. L. Turner. 1977. Taxonomy of Selinocarpus and Ammocodon (Nyctaginaceae). Phytologia 37: 177–208. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=levin2002a |text=Levin, R. A. 2002. Taxonomic status of Acleisanthes, Selinocarpus, and Ammocodon (Nyctaginaceae). Novon 12: 58–63. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=smith1976a |text=Smith, J. M. 1976. A taxonomic study of Acleisanthes (Nyctaginaceae). Wrightia 5: 261–276. }} }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes acutifolia |accepted_authority=Standley |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |place=12: 370. 1909 |year=1909 }} |common_names=Havard’s trumpets |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes acutifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes acutifolia]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 31, 34 |treatment_page=page 36 }}Plants herbaceous, overall pubescence mixture of capitate-glandular hairs 0.2–0.3 mm and white, capitate, shorter hairs 0.1–0.2 mm. Stems decumbent to ascending, much branched, 10–40 cm, hirtellous to glabrate. Leaves yellowish green, usually petiolate, distalmost sessile or nearly so, those of pair subequal; petiole 1–15 mm, puberulent to hirtellous; blade oval to oblong-elliptic, (5–)10–50 × 3–20(–25) mm, base acute to obtuse, margins crispate or undulate, apex apiculate and acute to obtuse or infrequently rounded; margins and adaxial midveins puberulent or occasionally hirtellous. Inflorescences solitary flowers, sessile or nearly so; bracts linear to subulate, 3–10 mm, hirtellous to puberulent. Flowers: chasmogamous perianth 2–5 cm, puberulent, tube 1–1.5 mm diam., limbs 10–30 mm diam., stamens 5; cleistogamous perianth 4–10 mm, hirtellous, stamens 2(–5). Fruits with 5 narrow sulci and 5 broad, smooth ribs extending past glands, each bearing sticky, resinous gland in constriction below apex, ovate-oblong, constricted 0.5–1 mm below apex, 5–8 mm, base tapering, apex truncate, sparsely puberulent or glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Calcareous or gypseous soils in grasslands and shrublands |elevation=700-2500 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Zacatecas). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes acutifolia |authority=Standley |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Calcareous or gypseous soils in grasslands and shrublands |elevation=700-2500 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Zacatecas). |reference=None |publication title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |publication year=1909 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_63.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes acutifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes angustifolia |accepted_authority=(Torrey) R. A. Levin |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Novon |place=12: 60. 2002 |year=2002 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Selinocarpus angustifolius |authority=Torrey |rank=species |publication_title=in W. H. Emory, Rep. U.S. Mex. Bound. |publication_place=2(1): 170, plate 47A. 1859 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes angustifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes angustifolia]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 38 }}Plants woody at base or throughout, overall moderately pubescent, with glandular hairs, also with minute white, curved, flattened, or T-shaped hairs. Stems erect or decumbent, sparsely leafy, 30–150 cm. Leaves dark green, often purplish, drying dark grayish green, sessile or petiolate, those of a pair slightly unequal, gradually reduced toward inflorescence, leathery-succulent; petiole 0–3 mm; blade linear, narrowly oblong, or lanceolate, 5–32 × 1–7 mm, base tapered, margins entire, apex acute or rounded and apiculate. Flowers 1(–2) in axils of distal leaves; pedicel 1–3 mm; perianth 10–15 mm, tube dark greenish yellow, limbs dull brownish orange, 6–8 mm diam.; stamens 5. Fruits 5–7 mm, puberulent with white flattened hairs; wings 1.5–2.5 mm wide.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Arid, well-drained, often rocky, igneous, calcareous, or gypseous soils |elevation=600-1000[-1800] m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes angustifolia |authority=(Torrey) R. A. Levin |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Selinocarpus angustifolius |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Arid, well-drained, often rocky, igneous, calcareous, or gypseous soils |elevation=600-1000[-1800] m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango). |reference=None |publication title=Novon |publication year=2002 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_68.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes angustifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes anisophylla |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |place=2, 15: 261. 1853 |year=1853 }} |common_names=Oblique-leaf trumpets |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes anisophylla |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes anisophylla]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 35 }}Plants herbaceous, overall pubescence of white, capitate hairs 0.1–0.2 mm. Stems decumbent, much branched, 3–15 cm, puberulent to glabrate. Leaves grayish green, sessile or more often petioled, those of pair very unequal (1 leaf 2–10 times length of other); petioles of smaller leaves to 12 mm, those of larger leaves 2–35 mm, puberulent to glabrate; blade ovate to oval-oblong or oval-rhombic, base rounded to obtuse, unequal and short decurrent, margins flat or very slightly undulate, apex acute to rounded or obtuse and apiculate, puberulent to glabrate; smaller blades 3–28 × 2–15 mm, larger blades 6–70 × 3–35 mm. Inflorescences solitary flowers, sessile or pedicellate; bracts linear-lanceolate to linear-subulate, 2–6 mm, sparsely puberulent; pedicel to 1 mm. Flowers: chasmogamous perianth 4–6 cm, puberulent, tube 10 mm diam., limbs 20–40 mm diam., stamens 5; cleistogamous perianth 1–3 mm, puberulent, stamens 5. Fruits with 10 equal ribs, without resinous glands, oval-oblong, truncate at both ends, slightly constricted beyond base, 3–6 mm, sparsely puberulent.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Rocky, gravelly, or sandy soils, limestone or shale outcrops in grasslands or shrublands |elevation=40-3500 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila;Nuevo León;Tamaulipas). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes anisophylla |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Rocky, gravelly, or sandy soils, limestone or shale outcrops in grasslands or shrublands |elevation=40-3500 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila;Nuevo León;Tamaulipas). |reference=None |publication title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |publication year=1853 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_59.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes anisophylla }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes chenopodioides |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) R. A. Levin |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Novon |place=12: 60. 2002 |year=2002 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Selinocarpus chenopodioides |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts., ser. |publication_place=2, 15: 262. 1853 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ammocodon chenopodioides |authority=(A. Gray) Standley |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes chenopodioides |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes chenopodioides]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34, 37 |treatment_page=page 38 }}Plants herbaceous, overall lightly pubescent with white, T-shaped minute hairs. Stems erect or ascending, sparsely to moderately leafy, 15–40 cm. Leaves dull green when fresh or dry, petiolate, those of a pair very unequal (the smaller often less than 1/2 the size of the larger), gradually reduced toward inflorescence, fleshy; petiole 5–45 mm; blade ovate to ovate-oblong or deltate, 15–50 × 6–40 mm, base rounded to subcordate, margins entire or undulate, apex acute, obtuse, or rounded. Flowers 3–25 in umbellate clusters, in forks of branches and distal axils, and terminal on branches; pedicel 1–4 mm; perianth 4–6 mm, tube greenish pink, limbs pink to lavender, 4–6 mm diam.; stamens 2(–3), widely spreading. Fruits 5 mm, puberulent with flattened, white hairs; wings 1.5–2 mm wide.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Dry, sandy, and gravelly areas, rock, gypseous clay |elevation=700-1700 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua). |discussion=

P. C. Standley (1916b) erected Ammocodon to accommodate this primarily morning-blooming species, based on its shorter perianth, fewer stamens, and umbellate inflorescences. B. A. Fowler and B. L. Turner (1977) maintained the genus separate from Selinocarpus. A. Heimerl (1934c) included the species in Selinocarpus, as did V. Bittrich and U. Kühn (1993). R. A. Levin (2000) presented evidence to support the inclusion of this species within a Selinocarpus clade within Acleisanthes, most closely allied to A. somalensis (Chiovenda) R. A. Levin.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes chenopodioides |authority=(A. Gray) R. A. Levin |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Ammocodon chenopodioides |basionyms=Selinocarpus chenopodioides |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Dry, sandy, and gravelly areas, rock, gypseous clay |elevation=700-1700 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua). |reference=None |publication title=Novon |publication year=2002 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_71.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes chenopodioides }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes crassifolia |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |place=2, 15: 260. 1853 |year=1853 }} |common_names=Texas trumpets |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes crassifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes crassifolia]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 36 }}Plants herbaceous, often slightly woody at base, overall pubescence of white, capitate hairs 0.1–0.2 mm. Stems procumbent, sparsely branched, 15–50 cm, hirtellous to glabrate. Leaves grayish green (major veins prominently paler), petiolate, those of pair slightly unequal; petiole 2–15(–20) mm, hirtellous; blade ovate to deltate-ovate or oblong-ovate, (5–)10–35(–45) × 2–20(–30) mm, base usually rounded, margins undulate, apex apiculate and acute or less frequently obtuse, sparsely puberulent abaxially and adaxially, adaxial primary and secondary veins hirtellous. Inflorescences solitary flowers, sessile or nearly so; bracts linear-lanceolate, 2–7 mm, long attenuate, usually puberulent. Flowers: chasmogamous perianth 3–5 cm, puberulent, tube 1–1.5 mm diam., limbs 8–25 mm diam., stamens 5; cleistogamous perianth 2–6 mm, hirtellous, stamens 2. Fruits with 5 broad, flat ribs, lacking grooves and resinous glands, 5-angled and shallowly 5-sulcate, oval-oblong, truncate at both ends, 6–9 mm, hirtellous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Rocky, calcareous soils in cenizo (Leucophyllum frutescens) shrublands and grasslands |elevation=200-700 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes crassifolia |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Rocky, calcareous soils in cenizo (Leucophyllum frutescens) shrublands and grasslands |elevation=200-700 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |publication year=1853 |special status=Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_62.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes crassifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes diffusa |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) R. A. Levin |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Novon |place=12: 61. 2002 |year=2002 }} |common_names=Spreading moonpod |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Selinocarpus diffusus |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |publication_place=2, 15: 262. 1853 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes diffusa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes diffusa]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34, 37 |treatment_page=page 36 }}Plants herbaceous, ± woody at base, overall moderately to densely pubescent with brownish, translucent, conic hairs, often with terminal cell whitish and flattened or brownish and spheroidal, and with appressed, white, flattened, minute, basally attached hairs. Stems erect, decumbent, or prostrate, densely leafy, 10–30 cm. Leaves dull green, commonly drying brownish green, petiolate, those of a pair slightly unequal, gradually reduced toward inflorescence, somewhat succulent; petiole 3–20 mm; blade ovate to ovate-oblong, 10–30 × 4–17 mm, base obtuse to truncate, margins undulate, apex acute to obtuse. Flowers usually 1 in axils of leaves; pedicel 1 mm; perianth 35–48 mm, tube pale dull green, limbs greenish white or pale greenish yellow, often with 5 greenish stripes, 15 mm diam.; stamens (4–)5. Fruits 5–7 mm with flattened, white hairs on body; wings 1–2 mm wide.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–late summer. |habitat=Dry clay and sandy, commonly calcareous or gypseous, soils |elevation=1100-1600 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes diffusa |authority=(A. Gray) R. A. Levin |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Selinocarpus diffusus |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–late summer. |habitat=Dry clay and sandy, commonly calcareous or gypseous, soils |elevation=1100-1600 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex. |reference=None |publication title=Novon |publication year=2002 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_65.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes diffusa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes lanceolata |accepted_authority=(Wooton) R. A. Levin |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Novon |place=12: 61. 2002 |year=2002 }} |common_names=Gyp moonpod |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Selinocarpus lanceolatus |authority=Wooton |rank=species |publication_title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |publication_place=25: 304. 1898 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes lanceolata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes lanceolata]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34, 37 |treatment_page=page 38 }}{{Treatment/Body |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex.;n Mexico. |discussion=

Varieties 2 (1 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes lanceolata |authority=(Wooton) R. A. Levin |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Selinocarpus lanceolatus |family=Nyctaginaceae |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex.;n Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Novon |publication year=2002 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_69.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes lanceolata }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Acleisanthes]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes lanceolata var. lanceolata |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Selinocarpus maloneanus |authority=B. L. Turner |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Acleisanthes lanceolata var. maloneana |authority= |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes lanceolata;Acleisanthes lanceolata var. lanceolata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes lanceolata]]
variety[[Acleisanthes lanceolata var. lanceolata]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 37 |treatment_page=page 38 }}Plants herbaceous or basally woody, lightly pubescent, hairs appressed, mostly retrorse, white, flattened, minute. Stems erect or decumbent, densely leafy, 10–50 cm. Leaves grayish green when fresh or dry, sessile or petiolate, those of a pair slightly unequal, gradually reduced toward inflorescence, thick and succulent; petiole 0–3 mm; blade lanceolate to broadly ovate, 12–40 × 4–13 mm, base obtuse or ± cordate, margins entire, apex acute or obtuse. Flowers 1(–2) in axils of distal leaves; pedicel 0–1 mm; perianth 30–42 mm, tube pale greenish, limbs cream or pale yellow, 10–15 mm diam.; stamens 5(–6). Fruits 6–9 mm, publerulent with flattened, white hairs; wings 2–4 mm wide.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Gypsum hills and flats |elevation=1000-1900 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (n Chihuahua). |discussion=

On average, Acleisanthes lanceolata leaves increase in breadth along a north-to-south gradient. B. A. Fowler and B. L. Turner (1977) recognized this variation at the varietal level, establishing Selinocarpus lanceolatus var. megaphyllus B. A. Fowler & B. L. Turner, a taxon restricted to gypsum outcrops in Chihuahua. In 1993, Turner revisited the complex, recognizing the Chihuahuan variety as S. megaphyllus (B. A. Fowler & B. L. Turner) B. L. Turner and established S. maloneanus (later reduced to varietal status) for populations in western Texas and northeastern Chihuahua, which have leaves averaging somewhat broader than those of var. lanceolatus. The perianth differences noted are variable. The “megaphyllus” phase is notably different from the “lanceolatus” phase. In at least some of the populations of S. megaphyllus, however, plants with typical “lanceolatus” foliage occur along with plants intergradient to broader-leaved forms. For this reason, Fowler and Turner’s approach of treating variation in the group at the varietal level is followed here. R. A. Levin (2002) did not recognized any varieties.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes lanceolata var. lanceolata |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Selinocarpus maloneanus;Acleisanthes lanceolata var. maloneana |basionyms= |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Gypsum hills and flats |elevation=1000-1900 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (n Chihuahua). |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_70.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes lanceolata |variety=Acleisanthes lanceolata var. lanceolata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes lanceolata]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes longiflora |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |place=2, 15: 260. 1853 |year=1853 }} |common_names=Angel trumpets;yerba de la rabia |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes longiflora |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes longiflora]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 31, 34 |treatment_page=page 35 }}Plants herbaceous, often slightly woody at base, overall pubescence of white, capitate hairs 0.2–0.4 mm. Stems ascending to prostrate or sprawling, profusely branched, to 100 cm, puberulent to glabrate, occasionally hirtellous. Leaves grayish green, petiolate, those of pair slightly unequal; petiole 1–14 mm, puberulent to glabrate; blade lanceolate to linear-lanceolate or triangular-lanceolate to deltate, 3–40 × 1–30 mm, base cuneate and decurrent, margins undulate or crispate, apex acuminate to acute or long attenuate, glaucous, puberulent to glabrate. Inflorescences solitary flowers, rarely geminate, sessile or with pedicel to 7 mm; bracts linear-subulate, 1–7 mm, puberulent to sparsely so. Flowers: chasmogamous perianth with tubes 7–17 cm × 1–2 mm, puberulent to glabrate, limbs 10–20 mm diam., stamens 5; cleistogamous perianth 5–12 mm, puberulent, stamens 5. Fruits with 5 hyaline ridges and pair of shallow, parallel grooves between ridges, without resinous glands, narrowly oblong, truncated at both ends, constricted 1 mm both below apex and above base, 6–10 mm, hirtellous to puberulent with capitate hairs and many to few, minute, moniliform hairs 0.2–0.4 mm, or glabrate.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Feb–Nov. |habitat=Rocky, gravelly, loamy, or sandy calcareous, gypseous, or igneous-derived soils in deserts, grasslands, shrublands, or woodlands |elevation=0-2500 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Nuevo León;Sonora;Tamaulipas). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes longiflora |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering Feb–Nov. |habitat=Rocky, gravelly, loamy, or sandy calcareous, gypseous, or igneous-derived soils in deserts, grasslands, shrublands, or woodlands |elevation=0-2500 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Nuevo León;Sonora;Tamaulipas). |reference=None |publication title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |publication year=1853 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_61.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes longiflora }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes nevadensis |accepted_authority=(Standley) B. L. Turner |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in B. L. Turner et al., Atlas Vasc. Pl. Texas, |place=7. 2003 |year=2003 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Selinocarpus diffusus subsp. nevadensis |authority=Standley |rank=subspecies |publication_title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |publication_place=12: 388. 1909 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Selinocarpus nevadensis |authority=(Standley) B. A. Fowler & B. L. Turner |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes nevadensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes nevadensis]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 37 }}Plants herbaceous or ± woody at base, overall moderately to densely pubescent with glandular hairs, with whitish, translucent, conic hairs (with or without large flattened and whitish terminal cell), and with appressed, white, flattened, minute hairs. Stems erect, decumbent, or prostrate, densely leafy, 8–30 cm. Leaves dull green, commonly drying yellowish green, petiolate, those of a pair slightly unequal, gradually reduced toward inflorescence, fleshy; petiole 3–20 mm; blade ovate to orbiculate, 8–30 × 4–17 mm, base obtuse to truncate, margins undulate, apex acute, obtuse, or rounded. Flowers usually 1 in axils of leaves; pedicel 1 mm; perianth 30–40 mm, tube pale dull green, limbs greenish white or pale greenish yellow, often with 5 greenish stripes, 10 mm diam.; stamens 5. Fruits 5–7 mm, puberulent with white, flattened hairs; wings 1.5–5 mm wide.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Dry rocky soils, commonly with Larrea |elevation=800-1000 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Nev.;Utah. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes nevadensis |authority=(Standley) B. L. Turner |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Selinocarpus nevadensis |basionyms=Selinocarpus diffusus subsp. nevadensis |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Dry rocky soils, commonly with Larrea |elevation=800-1000 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Nev.;Utah. |reference=None |publication title=in B. L. Turner et al., Atlas Vasc. Pl. Texas, |publication year=2003 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_66.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes nevadensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes obtusa |accepted_authority=(Choisy) Standley |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |place=12: 371. 1909 |year=1909 }} |common_names=Berlandier’s trumpets |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Nyctaginia obtusa |authority=Choisy |rank=species |publication_title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |publication_place=13(2): 429. 1849 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Acleisanthes berlandieri |authority=A. Gray |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Acleisanthes greggii |authority=Standley |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes obtusa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes obtusa]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 35 }}Plants herbaceous, often woody at base, overall pubescence of white, capitate hairs 0.1–0.2 mm. Stems prostrate or spreading, much branched, to more than 100 cm, hirtellous to glabrate. Leaves grayish green, sessile or petiolate, those of pair slightly unequal; petiole to 25 mm, hirtellous to glabrate; blade deltate to deltate-ovate, 2–30(–45) × 2–35(–50) mm, base truncate to subcordate or rounded and short decurrent, margins flat or slightly undulate, apex acute to broadly rounded and often apiculate, puberulent to glabrate. Inflorescences solitary flowers or 2–5-flowered cymes, sessile or with pedicel to 5 mm; bracts linear-subulate, 1–7 mm, puberulent, usually sparsely so. Flowers: chasmogamous perianth 2.5–5.5 cm, sparsely puberulent, tube 1–2 mm diam., limbs 13–25 mm diam., stamens 5; cleistogamous perianth 3–12 mm, puberulent, stamens 5. Fruits 5-ribbed with pair of parallel grooves between ribs, each rib and pair of grooves ending at summit in inconspicuous, glandless knob, oblong, truncate at both ends, often constricted ca. 1 mm above base and below apex, 5–8 mm, hirtellous to sparsely puberulent with capitate hairs and with few, scattered, moniliform hairs 0.2–0.3 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early spring–late fall. |habitat=Sandy, silty, or clay soils on calcareous or igneous substrates in grasslands, shrublands, or woodlands |elevation=0-1800 m |distribution=Tex.;s to c Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes obtusa |authority=(Choisy) Standley |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Acleisanthes berlandieri;Acleisanthes greggii |basionyms=Nyctaginia obtusa |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering early spring–late fall. |habitat=Sandy, silty, or clay soils on calcareous or igneous substrates in grasslands, shrublands, or woodlands |elevation=0-1800 m |distribution=Tex.;s to c Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |publication year=1909 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_60.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes obtusa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes parvifolia |accepted_authority=(Torrey) R. A. Levin |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Novon |place=12: 62. 2002 |year=2002 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Selinocarpus diffusus var. parvifolius |authority=Torrey |rank=variety |publication_title=in W. H. Emory, Rep. U.S. Mex. Bound. |publication_place=2(1): 168. 1859 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Selinocarpus parvifolius |authority=(Torrey) Standley |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes parvifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes parvifolia]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 37 }}Plants herbaceous or ± woody at base, overall moderately pubescent with glandular hairs and minute, appressed, white, flattened hairs with conic bases. Stems erect or ascending, sparsely leafy, 15–60 cm. Leaves yellow-green, drying dull brownish green, petiolate, those of a pair slightly unequal, abruptly reduced toward inflorescence, somewhat succulent; petiole 1–8 mm; blade ovate or ± diamond-shaped, 9–22 × 4–12 mm, base obtuse or ± cordate, margins entire or undulate, apex acute. Flowers usually 1 in axils of bracts in repeatedly forked inflorescences; pedicel 1–3 mm; perianth 34–52 mm, tube yellowish green, limbs pale yellowish green, 10–15 mm diam.; stamens 5. Fruits 8–10 mm, puberulent with glandular hairs and white flattened hairs; wings 2–4 mm wide.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Dry gypseous clays and shales |elevation=600-1000 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (ne Chihuahua). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes parvifolia |authority=(Torrey) R. A. Levin |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Selinocarpus parvifolius |basionyms=Selinocarpus diffusus var. parvifolius |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall. |habitat=Dry gypseous clays and shales |elevation=600-1000 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (ne Chihuahua). |reference=None |publication title=Novon |publication year=2002 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_67.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes parvifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acleisanthes wrightii |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) Bentham & Hooker f. ex Hemsley |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Biol. Cent.-Amer., Bot. |place=3: 6. 1882 |year=1882 }} |common_names=Wright’s trumpets |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Pentacrophys wrightii |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. |publication_place=2, 15: 261. 1853 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Acleisanthes;Acleisanthes wrightii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Acleisanthes]]
species[[Acleisanthes wrightii]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 34 |treatment_page=page 36 }}Plants herbaceous, overall pubescence mixture of capitate-glandular hairs 0.2–0.3 mm, and white, capitate, shorter hairs 0.1–0.2 mm. Stems erect or ascending to decumbent, much-branched, 10–40 cm, puberulent to glabrate. Leaves yellowish green, petiolate, those of pair subequal; petiole 1–15 mm, puberulent; blade oval to ovate-lanceolate or suborbiculate, 5–35 × 3–20 mm, base slightly unequal and obtuse to rounded or acute, margins crispate, apex apiculate and obtuse or infrequently acute, hirtellous to puberulent. Inflorescences solitary flowers, sessile or with pedicel to 1 mm; bracts linear-subulate, 2–8 mm, hirtellous to puberulent. Flowers: chasmogamous perianth 2.5–5 cm, puberulent to hirtellous, tube 1–1.5 mm diam., limbs 10–15 mm diam., stamens 5; cleistogamous perianth 3–8 mm, hirtellous, stamens 2(–5). Fruits prominently 5-ribbed and deeply 5-sulcate, ribs broad, smooth, each terminating in hemispheric, glandular tubercle, tubercule oblong, truncate at both ends, 5–9 mm, puberulent.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Various soils on calcareous substrates in grasslands or shrublands |elevation=200-1000 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acleisanthes wrightii |authority=(A. Gray) Bentham & Hooker f. ex Hemsley |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Pentacrophys wrightii |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Various soils on calcareous substrates in grasslands or shrublands |elevation=200-1000 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Biol. Cent.-Amer., Bot. |publication year=1882 |special status=Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_64.xml |genus=Acleisanthes |species=Acleisanthes wrightii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acleisanthes]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acmella |accepted_authority=Richard |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in C. H. Persoon, Syn. Pl. |place=2: 472. 1807 |year=1807 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae;Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae;Acmella |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae]]
subtribe[[Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae]]
genus[[Acmella]]
|etymology=From a Singhalese name for a plant now known as Blainvillea acmella (Linnaeus) Philipson |volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 64, 65, 67 |treatment_page=page 132 }}Annuals or perennials, 10–20(–30+) cm. Stems prostrate to erect, usually branched ± throughout. Leaves cauline; opposite; petiolate [± sessile]; blades (usually 3-nerved) ovate to rhombic or lanceolate [linear to filiform], bases ± cuneate, margins entire or toothed, faces sparsely pilose to strigillose, glabrescent. Heads radiate or discoid [disciform], borne singly at tips of branches [corymbiform arrays]. Involucres ± hemispheric to ovoid, 3–6+ mm diam. Phyllaries persistent, 8–15+ in 1–3 series (distinct, ovate to linear, subequal or outer longer). Receptacles conic, paleate (paleae falling with fruit, ± navicular, membranous to scarious, each about equaling subtended floret). Ray florets 0 or 5–20+, pistillate, fertile; corollas yellow to orange [white or purplish] (laminae ovate to linear) [wanting]. Disc florets 25–100(–200+) bisexual, fertile; corollas yellow [orange], tubes shorter than campanulate throats, lobes 4–5, deltate. Cypselae 2–3-angled (peripheral) or strongly compressed, ellipsoid to obovoid (glabrous or ciliate on the 2–3 angles or ribs); pappi 0, or fragile, of 1–3 awnlike bristles. x = 13.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=s United States;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America;introduced in Asia;Africa;Pacific Islands;Australia. |discussion=

Species 30 (2 in the flora).

Acmella pilosa R. K. Jansen has been reported as introduced in Florida (http://www.plantatlas.usf.edu); it differs from A. repens mainly by its more densely pilose stems and leaves and more truncate to cordate (versus cuneate) leaf bases.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=jansen1985a |text=Jansen, R. K. 1985. The systematics of Acmella (Asteraceae–Heliantheae). Syst. Bot. Monogr. 8: 1–115. }} }}

|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 132 |treatment_page=page 133 }}Leaves: petioles 3–40+ mm; blades ovate to lance-ovate, mostly 20–40(–100) × 10–35 mm, margins dentate to denticulate or entire. Cypselae 1–2.5 mm, ciliate or not, tips of cilia straight; pappi 0 or of 1–2(–3) bristles. 2n = 52.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jan–Dec. |habitat=Disturbed, wet or drying sites |elevation=0–200 m |distribution=Ala.;Ark.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acmella repens |authority=(Walter) Persoon |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Acmella oppositifolia var. repens;Spilanthes americana var. repens |basionyms=Anthemis repens |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jan–Dec. |habitat=Disturbed, wet or drying sites |elevation=0–200 m |distribution=Ala.;Ark.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Syn. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acoelorraphe |accepted_authority=H. Wendland |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) |place=37: 148. 1879 |year=1879 }} |common_names=Paurotis palm;palmier des Everglades |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Paurotis |authority=O. F. Cook |rank=genus }} |hierarchy=Arecaceae;Arecaceae subfam. Coryphoideae;Arecaceae tribe Corypheae;Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae;Acoelorraphe |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Arecaceae]]
subfamily[[Arecaceae subfam. Coryphoideae]]
tribe[[Arecaceae tribe Corypheae]]
subtribe[[Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae]]
genus[[Acoelorraphe]]
|etymology=Greek a-, without, coelo, hollow, and raphe, in reference to shape of the seed |volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 103 }}Plants moderate, clusteringed palms. Stems caespitose, erect, slender, less than 15 cm diam. Leaves: sheath fibers soft, eventually sloughing off to reveal smooth to fissured stem; petiole not split at base, armed with stout teeth, occasionally obscurely armed with minute teeth; abaxial hastula absent; adaxial hastula conspicuous, acute to acuminate; costa minute to absent; blade palmate; plication induplicate; segments lanceolate, stiff, basally connate. Inflorescences axillary within crown of leaves, paniculate, arching, longer than leaves, with 3(–4) orders of branching; prophyll short; peduncular bracts 2, tubular, 2-keeled, long; rachillae pendulous, pubescent. Flowers bisexual, borne singly or in clusters of 2–3 along rachillae, sessile; perianth 2-seriate; sepals 3, imbricate, briefly connate, margins ciliate; petals 3, basally connate, valvate, triangular with adaxial crest; stamens 6, filaments basally connate, acuminate; anthers dorsifixed, versatile; dehiscence latrorse-introrse; pistils 3(–4), distinct basally, glabrous; styles connate, filiform; stigmas minute. Fruits globose, stigmatic scar apical; exocarp blackish, smooth, slightly rugose when dry; mesocarp thin, fleshy; endocarp membranaceous. Seeds 1 per fruit, globose, with circular raphe; endosperm bony, homogeneous; embryo nearly basal; eophyll undivided, lanceolate. xn = 18.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Widespread;North America;se Mexico;West Indies;Central America;and n South America (Colombia–Isla de Providencia). |discussion=

Acoelorraphe is a widespread monotypic genus. The taxa A. wrightii forma inermis Hadacč and A. wrightii var. novo-geronensis Beccari probably have no biological significance.

Recent molecular studies indicated that Serenoa is the sister genus to Acoelorraphe (N. W. Uhl et al. 1995).

Species 1.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=galeano-garc1986a |text=Galeano-Garcés, G. 1986. Primer registro de dos géneros de palmas para la flora Colombiana. Mutisia 66: 1--4. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Acoelorraphe |authority=H. Wendland |rank=genus |parent rank=subtribe |synonyms=Paurotis |basionyms= |family=Arecaceae |distribution=Widespread;North America;se Mexico;West Indies;Central America;and n South America (Colombia–Isla de Providencia). |reference=galeano-garc1986a |publication title=Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) |publication year=1879 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_556.xml |subfamily=Arecaceae subfam. Coryphoideae |tribe=Arecaceae tribe Corypheae |subtribe=Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae |genus=Acoelorraphe }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Acoelorraphe wrightii |accepted_authority=(Grisebach & H. Wendland) H. Wendland ex Beccari |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Webbia |place=2: 109. 1907 |year=1907 }} |common_names=Paurotis palm;palmier des Everglades |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Copernicia wrightii |authority=Grisebach & H. Wendland |rank=species |publication_title=in A. H. R. Grisebach, Cat. Pl. Cub., |publication_place=220. 1866 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Acoelorraphe arborescens |authority=(Sargent) Beccari |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Acoelorraphe pinetorum |authority=Bartlett |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Paurotis androsana |authority=O. F. Cook |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Paurotis arborescens |authority=(Sargent) O. F. Cook |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Paurotis wrightii |authority=(Grisebach & H. Wendland) Britton. |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Arecaceae;Arecaceae subfam. Coryphoideae;Arecaceae tribe Corypheae;Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae;Acoelorraphe;Acoelorraphe wrightii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Arecaceae]]
subfamily[[Arecaceae subfam. Coryphoideae]]
tribe[[Arecaceae tribe Corypheae]]
subtribe[[Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae]]
genus[[Acoelorraphe]]
species[[Acoelorraphe wrightii]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 103 }}Stems multiple, brown, to 7 m, covered in tardily deciduous leaf bases. Leaves: petiole strongly (rarely weakly) armed; hastula present on adaxial surface. Inflorescences exceeding leaves, appearing secund because of pendulous rachillae, 15–22 cm, orange in fruit. Fruits ripening from green through orange to black, globose, 7.5–8.5 mm diam. 2n = 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Thin, rocky soil over limestone in hydric hammocks, wet savannas, and swamps of Everglades |elevation=0-10m |distribution=Fla.;se Mexico;West Indies (Bahamas;Cuba);Central America;n South America (Colombia-Isla de Providencia). |discussion=

Little is known about this palm in its natural habitats. In Florida, it occurs in the Everglades National Park and is categorized as threatened by the state of Florida. Like Serenoa repens, Acoelorraphe is tolerant of occasional burning. It is probably bee-pollinated, and the seeds are dispersed by birds (G. Galeano-Garcés 1986).

Of conservation concern.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Acoelorraphe wrightii |authority=(Grisebach & H. Wendland) H. Wendland ex Beccari |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Acoelorraphe arborescens;Acoelorraphe pinetorum;Paurotis androsana;Paurotis arborescens;Paurotis wrightii |basionyms=Copernicia wrightii |family=Arecaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–summer. |habitat=Thin, rocky soil over limestone in hydric hammocks, wet savannas, and swamps of Everglades |elevation=0-10m |distribution=Fla.;se Mexico;West Indies (Bahamas;Cuba);Central America;n South America (Colombia-Isla de Providencia). |reference=None |publication title=Webbia |publication year=1907 |special status=Illustrated;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_528.xml |subfamily=Arecaceae subfam. Coryphoideae |tribe=Arecaceae tribe Corypheae |subtribe=Arecaceae (tribe Corypheae) subtribe Livistoninae |genus=Acoelorraphe |species=Acoelorraphe wrightii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Acoelorraphe]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aconitum |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 532. 175 }}, {{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. Pl. ed. |place=5, 236. 1754 |year=1754 }} |common_names=Monkshood;aconite;wolfsbane;aconit |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aconitum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aconitum]]
|etymology=according to Pliny, the name "aconite" is taken from the ancient Black Sea port Aconis |volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, perennial, from tubers or elongate, fascicled roots. Leaves basal and cauline, proximal leaves petiolate, distal leaves sessile or nearly so; cauline leaves alternate. Leaf blade palmately divided into 3-7 segments, ultimate segments narrowly elliptic or lanceolate to linear, margins incised and toothed. Inflorescences terminal, sometimes also axillary, 1-32(-more) racemes or panicles, to 28 cm; bracts leaflike, not forming involucre. Flowers bisexual, bilaterally symmetric; sepals not persistent in fruit; lower sepals (pendents) 2, plane, 6-20 mm; lateral sepals 2, round-reniform; upper sepal (hood) 1, saccate, arched, crescent-shaped or hemispheric to rounded-conic or tall and cylindric, usually beaked, 10-50 mm; petals 2, distinct, bearing near apex a capitate to coiled spur, concealed in hood, long-clawed; nectary present, on spur; stamens 25-50; filaments with base expanded; staminodes absent between stamens and pistils; pistils 3(-5), simple; ovules 10-20 per pistil; style present. Fruits follicles, aggregate, sessile, oblong, sides prominently transversely veined; beak terminal, straight, 2-3 mm. Seeds deltoid, usually with small, transverse, membranous lamellae. x=8.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Circumboreal;southward into n Mexico and n Africa. |discussion=

Species ca. 100 (5 in the flora).

The greatest concentration of species of Aconitum is in Asia, with a smaller group in Europe.

Aconitum is phylogenetically most closely related to Delphinium Linnaeus as evidenced by similarities in karyotype, production of diterpene alkaloids, and similarities in floral morphology. Distinctive and unique floral morphology clearly distinguishes Aconitum from all other genera.

The aconites have been of interest since ancient times because they contain diterpene alkaloids that range from relatively nontoxic to deadly poisonous. In various parts of the world they have been used medicinally and as a source of poisons throughout history (D. E. Brink 1982). Use of Aconitum alkaloids in modern medicine was largely discontinued by the late 1930s and early 1940s (E. E. Swanson et al. 1938; H. C. Wood and A. Osol 1943; A. Osol et al. 1960).

Aconitum is a circumboreal arctic and alpine genus that extends into lower latitudes where there is suitable mesic habitat at high elevations along the north-south chains of mountains in eastern and western North America, and also in outlying, scattered, mesic, interglacial refugia, occasionally at low elevations.

The genus Aconitum worldwide is notorious for complex patterns of morphologic intergradation that blur the lines between taxa. Aconites from different regions may be morphologically distinct but connected by a series of intermediate races. Aconitum columbianum exemplifies this in North America, and A. delphiniifolium may extend this complex of variation into Asia. Intergradation between A. columbianum and A. delphiniifolium should be more fully investigated.

Cultivated aconites with origins outside North America sometimes persist in old gardens or are encountered as garden escapes, especially in eastern Canada (New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Nova Scotia, Ontario, and Quebec). These may include Aconitum lycoctonum Linnaeus, A. napellus Linnaeus, A. variegatum Linnaeus, and A.bicolor Schultes. Aconitum lycoctonum is similar to A. reclinatum of the southeastern United States in having the tall, conic-cylindric hood that is characterisitc of species in Aconitum sect. Lycoctonum de Candolle. Aconitum reclinatum has white flowers whereas A. lycoctonum has lilac-purple flowers.

Aconitum napellus and A. variegatum are European introductions with leaves divided to the base as in A. delphiniifolium, which is native to Canada and Alaska. The introduced species have taller hoods and relatively short-petiolate leaves compared to A. delphiniifolium; in A. delphiniifolium petioles are longer, i.e., mostly as long as blades. Aconitum napellus has smooth seeds that lack the undulating membranous lamellae present in A. delpinifolium and A. variegatum.

Aconitum bicolor is a reputed hybrid between A. napellus and A. variegatum, having leaves like the former and flowers similar to the latter. It is always sterile; seeds are not viable. Flowers of A. bicolor are frequently white with purple margins.

A more complete treatment of the cultivated aconites likely to be encountered in North America can be found in H. J. Scoggan (1978-1979, part 3, pp. 718-720) and P. A. Munz (1945).

Club 109: 13-23. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=brink1994a |text=Brink, D. E., J. A. Woods, and K. R. Stern. 1994. Bulbiferous Aconitum (Ranunculaceae) of the western United States. AconitumL. In: V. L. Komarov et al., eds. 1963+. Flora of the U.S.S.R. (Flora SSSR). Translated from Russian. 22+ vols. Jerusalem. Vol. 7, pp. 143-184. }} }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aconitum columbianum |accepted_authority=Nuttall |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in J. Torrey & A. Gray, Fl. N. Amer. |place=1: 34. 1838 |year=1838 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=W2 |label= }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aconitum;Aconitum columbianum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aconitum]]
species[[Aconitum columbianum]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Roots tuberous, tuber distally not obviously bulblike, to 60 × 15 mm, parent tuber producing 1 (rarely 2) daughter tubers with connecting rhizome very short, i.e., tubers ±contiguous. Stems erect and stout to twining and reclining, 2-30 dm. Cauline leaves: blade deeply 3-5(-7)-divided, usually with more than 2 mm leaf tissue between deepest sinus and base of blade, 5-15 cm wide, segment margins variously cleft and toothed. Inflorescences open racemes or panicles. Flowers commonly blue, sometimes white, cream colored, or blue tinged at sepal margins, 18-50 mm from tips of pendent sepals to top of hood; pendent sepals 6-16 mm; hood conic-hemispheric, hemispheric, or crescent-shaped, 11-34mm from receptacle to top of hood, 6-26 mm wide from receptacle to beak apex.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=B.C.;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Iowa;Mont.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;Nev.;Ohio;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;Moist areas;primarily in w North America;sporadic in e U.S. |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

Available information suggests that Aconitum columbianum is probably not one of the extremely toxic aconites (D. E. Brink 1982; J. D. Olsen et al. 1990).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=brink1980a |text=Brink, D. E. 1980. Reproduction and variation in Aconitum columbianum (Ranunculaceae), with emphasis on California populations. Amer. J.Bot. 67: 263-273. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=brink1980b |text=Brink, D. E. and J. M. J. de Wet. 1980. Interpopulation variation in nectar production in Aconitum columbianum (Ranunculaceae). Oecologia 47: 160-163. }} }}
